bibliographic_metadata.Journal: Proceedings of the Nigerian Society of Physical Sciences
bibliographic_metadata.Title: Multisource data fusion for enhanced gold mineral prospectivity mapping in Yagba West, Kogi State: a machine learning approach
bibliographic_metadata.Author: Momohjimoh Abdulsalami, Jacob Funsho Omonile, Abubakar Fahad, Abdullateef Aliyu, Muhammad Kabir Yahaya

abstract: Gold mineral prospectivity mapping is crucial for identifying potential gold-bearing zones and supporting exploration efforts through advanced data analytics. This study applied Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Classification and Regression Trees (CART) to generate gold mineralization maps for Yagba West, utilizing an integrated dataset comprising SRTM DEM, Landsat 8 imagery, geological maps, and aeromagnetic data. The SVM model mapped a 249.58 km² gold-prospective area with 96% validation accuracy, while the CART model identified 132.13 km² with 97% accuracy. The findings underscore the potential of machine learning in enhancing gold prospectivity mapping and optimizing exploration strategies.
methodology: supervised > tree-based > random forest; supervised > tree-based > decision tree (CART)
key_points: Utilized SVM and CART for gold mineralization mapping.
SVM identified a larger area (249.58 km²) compared to CART (132.13 km²).
Both models demonstrated high classification performance.
Gold occurrences are concentrated in quartzite and schist formations.
Machine learning enhances exploration strategies in structurally controlled terrains.
